Brussels sources claimed she was “not convincing” when she addressed EU leaders and insisted that her deal could still be passed, and that she failed to set out a plan B. Asked how long the “long extension” eventually on offer to the UK could be, European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker replied: “Until the very end.” Mrs May stressed her opposition to the EU poll - but did not rule out that it could happen. “I believe strongly that it would be wrong to ask people in the UK to participate in the elections three years after voting to leave the EU,” she said.    In a major climbdown, she also conceded that Parliament could end up taking control of the process.A cross-party group of MPs have already announced plans for a series of votes on alternative plans next Wednesday. Tory Brexiteers are likely to be furious that Mrs May has opened the door to a longer delay - or Brexit no happening at all.But with just seven days to go until Brexit, fears were rising that Mrs May could be willing to swing behind a catastrophic No Deal Brexithers falls once again.Unions and business leaders have warned Theresa May about a looming national emergency as Britain edges closer to a no-deal Brexit. TUC general secretary Frances O’Grady and CBI director general Carolyn Fairbairn urged the PM to take swt action to protect jobs and rights. In a joint letter to Mrs May, they demanded she avoids a no-deal exit and comes up with a plan B.  They said: “Our country is facing a national emergency. The shock to our economy would be felt by generations to come... “Decisions of recent days have caused the risk of no deal to soar. Firms and communities across the UK are not ready for this outcome.” It comes as it emerged military planning for a no-deal has begun in a nuclear bunker under the Ministry of Defence. Around , troops are on standby as part of Operation Redfold. Mrs May’s chances of her getting her deal through the Commons still look remote as MPs reacted furiously to her attempts to blame them for her own chaotic handling of the Brexit process.Her own chief whip, Julian Smith, was reported to have openly admitted he found the statement “appalling”. The televised message was also described as a “low blow” by former Tory minister Sam Gyimah.Labour MPs in Leave seats, who she needs to get her deal through, appeared to be backing away. Wigan MP Lisa Nandy said: “There’s absolutely no chance she is going to win over MPs in sufficient numbers after that statement. “I will not support a Government that takes such a reckless, dangerous approach.”    Mrs May, asked last night whether she would apologise for trying to sht the blame onto MPs, offered a partial climbdown - but it was unlikely to be enough. She said: “There are passionately held views on all sides of this argument “Last night I expressed my frustration and know they are frustrated too. MPs have a dficult job to do.” Tory Brexiteers were also bolstered by the belief that a short delay made a no-deal Brexit more likely.Some who switched to back her deal last week were considering U-turning to oppose it again. As leaders arrived at the Brussels summit, EU leaders had stark words of warning for the PM. French President Emmanuel Macron said it was heading for no-deal should MPs reject Mrs May’s plan again. Irish PM Leo Varadkar said “no-deal,it happens, will be a British choice and a British decision”.  A petition to cancel Brexit has already received over . million signatures just a day after it was started. The official Parliament petition website crashed several times yesterday because of the volume of people adding their names. The petition, set up by Margaret Anne Georgiadou, to revoke Article  has been backed by celebrities including actor Hugh Grant and scientist Brian Cox. Independent Group MP Heidi Allen also signed it and, more surprisingly, Camilla Cavendish who was the Director of Policy for then prime minister David Cameron. Petitions that secure , signatures receive an official response, while those that gain more than , signatures have to be debated. Officials have confirmed that the earliest the petition could be debated is on Tuesday.

story: NewsJeremy Corbyn to meet Theresa May on Monday in bid to stave off No Deal BrexitSpeaking to the Mirrors Pippa Crerar in Brussels, Mr Corbyn said he will sit down with the PM ahead of her third attempt to get her deal through the CommonsShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video jeremy-corbyn-gives-exclusive-video-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Jeremy Corbyn has agreed to th hour talks with Theresa May in a bid to head off a catastrophic No Deal Brexit .The Mirror can reveal he will sit down with the Prime Minister on Monday ahead of her third attempt to get her deal through the Commons.In an exclusive interview, the Labour leader said: “We’re the responsible party here. We’re not running down the clock, we’re looking for solutions”.But Mr Corbyn revealed the only way Labour would back the PM’s deal wasshe agreed to move towards a softer Brexit. “If she could say she’s prepared to understand what we’re saying, the points we’re making about the future - customs union, dynamic relationship with Europe - then we will be able to talk to her about that,” he said. “She’s got to move forward on how things can change.” After talks in Brussels, Mr Corbyn warned that Left-wing EU leaders were “frustrated” with Mrs May’s handling of Brexit and “anxious” about the UK crashing out by accident. “It’s a very real threat obviously and it’s made worse by the PM preicating,” he said. “I’m very clear where the responsibility lies for where we’ve got to. The party will then back a cross-party amendment focused on the UK’s future trading relationship with the EU, as well as workers’ rights. But it remains unclear whether there is a consensus in Parliament around a softer Brexit.The smaller opposition parties, including the SNP and the Lib Dems, are opposed to leaving the EU in any form and want a second referendum instead.But Tory Remainers working on a dferent way forward are opposed to a public vote. Mr Corbyn insisted: “I do believe that we can get there”.  He claimed his fellow leaders “get it” that Brexit is happening irrespective and “fully understand” the dangers of No Deal. And he said that Labour, which officially has kept a second referendum on the table despite Mr Corbyn’s private misgivings, would “certainly do our best to meet them” on a fresh vote. The Labour leader admitted striking a balance between referendum-supporting Labour MPs and members, and Leave voters who backed the party at the last election, was sometimes dficult. “I realise the tensions and I realise the pressures. My purpose is to prevent No Deal, to bring people together and keep the Labour Party together,” he said. “Of course it’s complicated but we weren’t sent into this le to have an easy time.”    He defended his decision to boycott a cross-party meeting convened by the PM because former Labour MP Chuka Umunna was there to represent the Independent group. Parliament’s job is to hold Government to account... that’s what MPs are elected to do,” he said. “The fact that Parliament has comprehensively disagreed with her on many occasions doesn’t mean Parliament isn’t doing its job, it means it’s saying that what she’s proposing is unacceptable.” He agreed with some Labour MPs who have claimed the PM’s words had increased the risk of threats. title: only could jacinda ardern sort
story: NewsopinionIf only we could have Jacinda Ardern to sort out our chaosWhy cant Theresa May be more like New Zealand PM, Jacinda Ardern who has shown what a natural-born leader can doShareCommentsByPaul Routledge:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsopinionJacinda Ardern "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf only Theresa were more like Jacinda maybe we wouldn’t be in this mess. New Zealand’s Labour prime minister rose magnicently to the occasion when a hate-crazed assassin struck in Christchurch, killing  Muslim worshippers. Straight into the thick of it, taking charge and bringing the people with her, Jacinda Ardern was all that a democratic leader should be. This slightly-built, witheringly articulate woman who was only named her party’s leader the month before becoming PM in , spoke for her nation asshe had been born for such a challenge.    Compare her handling of a national crisis with Theresa May’s ham-fisted, ­incoherent command of Brexit. The contrast is embarrassing. Mrs May is a politician’s politician: more than two decades as an MP, chairwoman of the Tory Party, holder of a string of ministerial offices and six years as Home Secretary, before taking over from David Cameron as PM in . But she’s not a natural leader. Jacinda is, and it shows. A one-time policy adviser to Tony Blair, this -year-old starter-premier could tell veteran Theresa a thing or two about doing the job. Like how to conduct ­yourself with people.    Mrs May is gauche, wooden and lacking in empathy. She came late to the Grenfell fire tragedy, and failed to win hearts and minds. Mrs Kiwi gets in there, talks the talk with victims’ families, and then walks the walk with tough new curbs on gun ownership. You can tell she gets it. If only we could get her, or somebody like her, to lead us out of this chaos. Time is running short. Mrs May signals she’s had enough, and might quit in the summer. No other person in her party is fit to succeed her, which is not surprising: there’s no such thing as a Tory Jacinda.

title: brexit bored britain leaving funny
story: AdvertorialFrom sex to scones - why Brits are being forced to chat about embarrassing subjectsHere are some topics of conversation to take your mind off the EU madnessShareByDave Masters:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Advertorial"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf there’s one thing the British people can do well, it’s small talk.We talk about the weather , we talk about our holiday plans - and in our more adventurous moments we talk about the news of the day. But you know what we’re sick of chatting about  Brexit .It was all supposed to be sorted by now - and quite frankly, it was boring to begin with. But since it’s dragging its heels - and could be going on even longer than we feared - British chit-chatters are being forced to talk about subjects normally off limits, on grounds of taste and embarrassment. Here’s some of the topics of conversation that, while awkward or tedious, still seem more riveting than Brexit at this point.Climate Change The almost inevitable fiery death of our planet  Rising oceans and apocalyptic storms  The certain death of every human, animal and plant - and the demise of millions of years of human history and culture, like so much ash blowing away on the wind Yep, still more fun than talking about the Northern Ireland Backstop.ReligionThe classic ‘never bring this up on a first date’ subject. It’s fraught with danger - from setting up articial barriers with a potential partner, to finding out you’ve just bought a gin and slim for a member of the Church of Scientology.    But ask me whether I’d rather start a love affair with a question about god, or spend time discussing ‘that nice Nigel Farage fellow, he’s just saying what everyone  is thinking’ with an elderly relative  Hand us the bible, babes.Sex As a nation we are prudish folk. Many of us would be utterly mortied to be forced to discuss the ins and outs of our bedroom encounters. Mainly for fear of finding out we’d been doing it wrong all these years, I think. But even the most puritanical Brit would rather wax lyrical about their deepest boudoir secrets than debate the relative merits of deal or no deal.Whether cream or jam goes on firstWars have been started over lesser disagreements than the construction of the great British cream tea scone. Itaposs half the reason Cornwall would like to be an independent state, as we understand it.    But that is nothing - NOTHING - compared to the furious rows that can explode from the question “ the Leave campaign cheated, shouldn’t we have a do-over ”Other people’s babies “Oh, you’ll never guess what darling little Olivia did yesterday, it was the absolute cutest thing ever. She put, like, her entire fist in her mouth and made this gurgly, dribbling sound. Hang on, I’ve got a video of it on my phone.” We love our offspring. But even babies that belong to us are often boring. We don’t want to talk about infants for which we have no responsibility. But we’d still rather chat about how many teeth little Jack has got now than how much we’ll be paying Brussels in the orce settlement.Interior design“Hey man, that’s a great shelving unit - where’s it from ” “Ikea.” “Nice. Love your sofa too. The way it transforms into a full-size double bed is just so convenient and innovative! Where’s it from ” “Ikea.” We all love looking at pictures of lovely rooms on Pinterest and flicking through catalogues of dining tables we will never be able to afford. But we do that alone. Interior design is not a fun group chat topic.  Still less bleak than talking about the Political Declaration on the Future Relationship.Your holiday snaps I didn’t go on your holiday. It doesn’t look like the kind of holiday I would enjoy. Iceland doesn’t seem to have any beaches, just luke-warm rock pools and knitting.But we would sit through a three-hour slideshow of all the fun things you and the weirdo youaposre dating did during your magical fortnight in Reykjavik - including your blurry, underexposed pictures of the Northern Lights. We’d even pretend gasp, and tell you it looks like a dream come true. We’d do all of this before we would consider entering into a conversation about whether Article  can be withdrawn without a motion being passed in Parliament.MarmiteThe great ide in this country isn’t leave or remain, it’s “yeast extract: nectar of the angels or the devil’s armpit scrapings ” And yet I would listen to you talk for hours about Marmite. Hell, I’d EAT marmite before I suggest a casual chat about whether free movement of people has depressed wages in struggling Northern communities.Non-league football

story: NewsI booked my mums flight home even though she was going to Switzerland to dieTom Beagley-Spicer travelled with his mum to Dignitas so she could end her le but he was so worried about repercussions he hid away after her deathShareCommentsByHelen Whitehouse:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsTom with his mum Susan, before she travelled to Switzerland to end her le "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email It took  seconds for Susan Spicer to pass away - a moment sheaposd been waiting for  years.Her son Tom Beagley Spicer was by her side and stayed with her as she took her last breath, slipping a heart-shaped chocolate into her pocket. Tom had already grieved for Susan long before she passed away, learning the exact date of her death months previously when she booked into Dignitas.Susan had suffered with multiple sclerosis for the majority of her le, was blind and had battled breast cancer.Although the hardest part was letting his beloved mum, , go, he knew she needed to be in control. And heaposs not alone in his fear Geoffrey Whaley wanted to die before his Motor Neurone disease took hold, so like Susan, he went to Dignitas to end his le. He released an open letter addressed to MPs denouncing the UK laws on assisted suicide and pleading with them to change the law after his we was interviewed by police over his death. Tom was worried about criminal repercussions but put on a brave face as he knew it was what his mum wanted.    Ever since Tom was  and living with his grandparents after his mumaposs health declined, Dignitas had been discussed. Not everyone had access to the internet, I remember the early days in the late s looking online and the Dignitas website wasnapost even converted into English. There were certain bits you just couldnapost understand - it was so secretive. It was a taboo subject, a criminal activity. For all of our lives, and still today, you are looking at a process where you are meant to feel like a criminal. But in  as the pair ate lunch Susan told Tom sheaposd had enough. He said: Mum spent the three months beforehand building me so many memories in places I liked. It keeps me going, she did it with me. I remember sitting at the airport, weaposd had breakfast and I was flapping about trying to keep busy. It was unreal. The scary bit is you see a doctor twice in Switzerland, he may not approve you, you may come back as a three. Deep down I knew mum wasnapost coming back and it was just so unreal - she wanted it, sheaposd lost her sight, use of her arms and legs and mobility. This was the last bit of control she had left. He said it was a bizarre feeling knowing his mum wasnapost coming home with him but was determined to be as positive as possible. Tom said: We had a bloody good time in the first two days. title: welcome worlds oldest horse race
story: NewsWelcome to the worlds OLDEST horse race - first run in Henry VIIIs timeWorlds oldest horse race the quintennial Kiplingcotes Derby, or the Fast Riding of Yorkshire, celebrates  YEARS of sporting actionShareByPaul Routledge:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsThe new Kiplingcotes Derby winning post in the early s "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHenry the Eighth was on the throne when the Kiplingcotes Derby was first run. But, like Richard III, he would have given his kingdom for a horse to ride in yesterday’s th anniversary event. A record field of  runners and riders turned out to celebrate the quintennial competition in brilliant sunshine on the Yorkshire Wolds. The challenge is a thrilling gallop in the world’s oldest continuously-run race, across four miles of farm tracks and country lanes. The winner’s reward is scarcely regal - nobbut your name on a silver horse cup and fty quid, with the wildcard hazard of runner-up scooping the pool of entry fees.  This is horse-racing, but not as Ascot or Aintree knows it. No advance registration of mounts, no famous jockeys and no upfront betting odds: just turn up, weigh up, saddle up and they’re off!From the air, it would have looked like a festival of flat caps. At ground level, a celebration of tweed. Rural East Riding at its most farming traditional. Jeremy Corbyn would hardly have been recognised.Under a cloudless sky, riders had the public indignity of weighing in to ensure they were at least ten stone. Some underweight competitors slip lead weights into their clothes to meet the target. Hundreds gathered in classic David Hockney country to watch this extraordinary event. The horses were as coloured and ied as their names: Red Panther, Harry, Matty, Asia, The Duchess, Chocobox, The World’s Worst. Favourites of home stables, all.    The ancient rule - “whosoever doth stop or stay any of the horses that rideth for this prize...shall win no prize” is read out. Then they hacked down the course to the starting point before belting back to the finishing line. The whole affair takes not much more than ten minutes. Some of these thoroughbred horses looked suspiciously like they had last seen grass at Cheltenham. I counted them out and counted them in. No falls this year, all safely home, though riders count this a dangerous as well as thrilling competition. Tracey Corrigan was first home by several s on Frog, romping away from Jason Carver on StartMeUp. Tracey, a local huntswoman, hugged her horse. “He’s my boy. He’s my man. He thinks I’m his mother. We have a super relationship. I call him Frog because he’s French. Andyou kiss him he turns into a prince. “I’m very proud. I’m a happy hacker, and I don’t like to lose. People don’t believe me but second is first loser in my house. I was looking for a new home for Frog, but I might change my mind now.    Runner-up Jason, a lithe enthusiast looks the part more than most, with blue and white jockey’s colours told a fellow-rider: “I thought we had a chance about a mile out, but no.” The one-time winner of the Newmarket Town Plate, the longest race in the country, he assured me, would have been entitled to hundreds of pounds as runner-up taking all the £. entry fees bar the money for the prize. He was cheered for handing the cash back to the Injured Jockeys Fund. Tracey is now a four-times winner, having come first in ,  and . She was on short odds – - with the sole course bookie Chris Johnson, who comes here every year from Doncaster. “I don’t usually take much but this year looks promising.” He watches theweigh-in where riders are checked to seetheir weight has slipped below ten stones “so there’s no skulduggery.” Nothing of that sort here. This is Tyke territory, not Jilly Cooper country. “Craps odds!” mumbles a racegoer behind me. In fact, from - to -, minimum stake £, maximum £.    The cash had rolled in. I’d bet £ to win on Pudding, ridden by Becky Oxley, assuming the name had something to do with Yorkshire’s finest dish. “Oh no, I call him that because he was a bit fat when I bought him. I trimmed him down but Pudding was his pet name and it just stuck.” Tradition dictates thatthe course is not completed in any one year, then the Derby dies. Last year, it had to be cancelled because off-road vandals damaged the course.    So sole rider Stephen Crawford and his mount Firkin walked the route to comply with Rule  that says for the race to continue, an inidual and his mount must complete the course after being weighed in. The ancient rules state: “A horse race to be observed and ridd yearly on the third Thursday of March, open to horses of all ages, to convey horsemen’s weight, ten stones, exclusive of saddle, to enter ye post before eleven o’clock on the morning of ye race. The race to be run before two.”    They came from far and wide, well, much of Hockney country anyway Rebecca Wood, , and her one year-old son Douglas were there to cheer on Dougal. “It’s the first year I’ve been. It’s nice to bring children. In the grass sat two young women and an infant with a placard for their horse. Little cameos like that abound, old England in the sticks, just like it should be. As for my winning ways, the odds on Pudding ened from  to - before they even broke into a sweat. He came in very low down the field. “I told you not to back him,” said Becky, . So what went wrong  “He had to stop to talk to somebody. I didn’t want to do it but it was the th. He won’t be doing it again.” But others will. “The Derby will still be here in another five hundred years,” insists Tracey. “It’s a shame we won’t be.”

title: monkey born frozen testicular tissue
story: NewsMonkey born from frozen testicular tissue offer hope to young cancer patientsThe birth of the animal was a "major step" towards developing fertility-restoring treatments for boys who undergo potentially sterilising proceduresShareCommentsBySally Wardle:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsGrady, a macaque, at two weeks old born in April , via in vitro fertilization "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA monkey has been born after scientists successfully froze and thawed testicular tissue using a technique which could offer hope to young cancer patients. Experts said the study, published in journal Science, was a major step towards developing fertility-restoring treatments for boys who undergo potentially sterilising procedures. Treatments like chemotherapy can lead to infertility and, while it is possible for men to freeze their sperm ahead of treatment, pre-pubescent males are too young to produce it. The scientists, from the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, removed a testis from five young rhesus macaques and froze the testicular tissue. The animals then underwent chemotherapy.    As the animals approached puberty, the researchers thawed the tissue samples and implanted them back in the animals, along with fresh tissue from the remaining testis. The team found that after a few months, the tissue had produced sperm, which was used to generate embryos and transferred to females. Grady, a healthy female rhesus macaque, was born in April . Dr Adetunji Fayomi, one of the studyaposs authors, said: With Gradyaposs birth, we were able to show proof-of-principle that we can cryopreserve pre-pubertal testicular tissue, and later use it to restore fertility as an adult. Dr Kyle Orwig, the studyaposs senior author, added: This advance is an important step toward offering young cancer patients around the world a chance at having a family in the future. Dr Rod Mitchell, from the University of Edinburgh, said: This study represents a major step towards developing treatments for restoring fertility potential in boys facing sterilising cancer treatment.    Since , we have been freezing and storing testicular tissue in boys at high risk of future infertility as a result of their cancer treatment. This study provides proof-of-principle for restoring fertility potential in these boys when they reach adulthood. This is the first primate study to show that pre-pubertal testicular tissue can be successfully removed, cryopreserved and re-transplanted, resulting in the development of sperm that can generate a live birth. Whilst translation of this approach into humans will require carefully conducted clinical studies, for young boys currently having their testicular tissue cryopreserved these results provide genuine optimism for their future fertility.

story: NewsMum who thought her kitchen floor was dark grey disgusted to learn the truthA mum couldnt believe her eyes when she discovered her kitchen floor tiles were actually a completely dferent colour than she thoughtShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsMum shocked by kitchen floor transformation "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Thanks to the likes of Mrs Hinch, weaposre all being inspired to find new, creative ways to clean our homes. Recently, we discovered that tomato ketchup is an unlikely item you can use to make your sink sparkle.But when it comes to scrubbing floors, one mum has found an impressive method of making a room look brand new. Jade Jenkins, from Brisbane, Australia, was recently shocked to learn that her dark kitchen floor was actually meant to look very dferent and that it was a lot dirtier than she realised.   Posting in Facebook group, Mums Who Clean, the woman shared before and after shots of her kitchen tiles and the two look like they could be in dferent homes.After living in a rented property for a while, the mum simply thought her kitchen floor was a dark grey colour. title: dundee boss mcintyre refuses to blame referee for celtic loss after 96th minute goal
story: Boss Jim McIntyre believes the six minutes of injury time played by Bobby Madden at Dens Park yesterday was too long.However, the Dundee gaffer refused to blame the referee for the heart-breaking loss to Celtic that came via an Odsonne Edouard strike in the final few seconds of that extra period.When he did finally blow for time, home supporters booed the whistler off the park and clearly believed he’d cost their team a point.For Jim, though, the failure to take an excellent opportunity to snatch victory just seconds earlier was the cause of his team’s agonising demise.That came when substitute Andy Dales shot straight at Hoops keeper Scott Bain from the edge of the area when a better option seemed to play a pass.It allowed Celtic to go up the park and capitalise on an error by home skipper Martin Woods and grab the winner.“I fail to see where six minutes comes from. I thought that was too much time added on but, having said that, it’s not the reason,” he said.“We had a great opportunity on the counter attack with two minutes to go and we’ve got to be better.“That’s the reason we are where we are because we’ve been going into so many good areas in each of the last few games and we’re not punishing teams.“We didn’t do what Celtic did. They were ruthless and that’s why we’ve not picked up enough points since I’ve come.“There has been plenty of positive play, plenty of areas we’ve got into but we need to be better in the final third.“It’s the only thing that’s going to get you out of the situation that you’re in – winning games.”Returning to Madden’s decision to play on for so long, Jim confirmed he had spoken to the referee to get his reasoning.“He said there were a couple of head knocks, so that was the reason why. It’s generally about three but there were a couple of knocks, so I could understand maybe four. Six was a surprise.”The defeat, along with Hamilton Accies’ surprise win over Hearts on Saturday, means Dundee are now six points from safety down in the top flight drop zone.The postponement of St Mirren’s game at St Johnstone on Saturday because of snow means the Dark Blues remain a point above bottom.

title: dundee fc apologises over incident involving irish flag being taken from celtic fan
story: Dundee FC has released a statement following an incident in which an Irish flag was taken from a Celtic supporter.Posts showed a steward apparently reaching up and grabbing the flag as it was draped over an advertising hoarding above the tunnel as Dundee played hosts to Celtic at Dens Park.A club spokesman said the manner in which the flag was taken was #not acceptable# and blamed a #communication breakdown# for the incident.mdash Adam O#BrianMarch , Stewards were seen to take the flag in a Twitter post, and a separate video showing an argument in the tunnel was also uploaded to the social media site.mdash Stephen Roberts 🍀March , A spokesman said: #The club would advise that the enquiries into the #flag# incident which took place at Sunday’s match vs. Celtic are now concluded.#These enquiries have revealed a clear breakdown in communication and decision making and moving forward, this needs to be and will be addressed by the club in conjunction with all members of the event management team.#Clearly, the method employed to remove the item from the advertising board was not acceptable and out with the agreed procedures for dealing with matters of this nature.#The clubs and the two supporters involved have met and discussed the issue at greatand Dundee Football Club would wish to convey our sincere thanks for the cooperation of all concerned.#In the spirit of the discussions which took place at this meeting, Dundee Football Club would wish to place on record our sincere apologies to the two supporters involved in this incident.#We will always endeavour in future to strive to achieve a safe and secure environment for everyone here at the Kilmac Stadium at Dens Park.#

title: dundee supporters society rejects bid from club owner to buy groups shares
story: Dundee’s main supporters group have knocked back the latest offer from the club’s American owner to buy shares from them and increase his stake at Dens Park to over %.But while they’re unwilling to sell any of their shares, the Dundee FC Supporters’ Society have repeated support for plans to move to a new stadium near the city’s Camperdown Park.In January, Texas-based Tim Keyes, through majority shareholders in the Dark Blues Football Partners Scotland which he owns, had a move to buy the society’s ‘A’ Ordinary shares refused.They’re the shares that hold the power of veto over such matters as any sale of the club, a move from Dens and even substantial borrowing.Earlier this month Keyes then made an offer for the society’s Ordinary shares, a move that would give him .% of Dundee shares and the club said would allow them to claim Group Tax Relief to offset losses.After discussions with the club and their own membership, however, the society’s board have decided that’s a non-starter as well.In an alternative proposal, the club had asked the society to “agree to support resolutions which increase the club’s share capital and then allot shares specically to FPS”.That, too, however, has been rejected. The society board have now informed Dens financial director David Gray and their own members of the decision to hang on to all their shares.Given there’s no provision in society rules for the sale of any shares and their rejection of the original attempt to get their veto-holding shares, this latest move comes as no surprise, particularly as even an improved offer of £, for the ordinary shares was viewed as derisory by many members.Dundee are now likely to undertake a full share issue that would allow Keyes to break through the % barrier but is likely to entail administrative costs running into five figures.

title: dundee united confirm departure of laurie ellis
story: Dundee United have confirmed former assistant boss Laurie Ellis’ departure from Tannadice.As the Tele revealed at the time, the former Raith Rovers stalwart was put on gardening leave back in January.United made no comment at the time but, in a statement today, announced the -year-old is no longer their employee.“As we continue to review all areas of the club and put in place our plans for the long-term vision we have for Dundee United, Laurie leaves with our thanks for his effort and commitment during his near-three seasons at Tannadice and our best wishes for his future coaching career,” said sporting director Tony Asghar.Ellis arrived at Tannadice as No  when Ray McKinnon was appointed manager in .He continued in that role under Csaba Laszo and for the first three-and-a-bit months of Robbie Neilson’s reign.“I am proud and honoured to have played a role at Dundee United,” he said today.“This is a fantastic club that has the potential to be in the Premiership and, while I wish that could have been achieved in my time here, I wish everyone at United all the best in their pursuit of promotion.“I now look forward to the next stage in my career.”Earlier this month reserve team manager Craig Easton and U  coach Scott Robertson were also stood down from their duties.To date, United have not commented on their situations.

title: dunfermline eventually say sorry to fans for late call off of dundee united game
story: Dunfermline have apologised to fans after the late call-off of Saturday’s Championship clash with Dundee United.United were already at East End Park and most of their travelling support were close to completing their journey when the game was called off just  minutes before kick-off.That was despite the Pars insisting from first thing in the morning that, despite heavy snow and torrential rain, the pitch would be fine.When, however, match referee David Lowe inspected the pitch at around .pm it took him no more than a couple of minutes to give the snow-covered surface the thumbs down because it was waterlogged.That saw the United squad get straight back on the team bus and depart within minutes.The news was too late for some fans of both clubs and they arrived at the stadium to find there was to be no game.Other than confirm the game was off, referee Lowe declined to comment further.And, initially, the home club also refused to provide an explanation.Later, however, they did make a statement via their official website.“Following the cancellation of this afternoon’s match against Dundee United, DAFC would like to apologise to all home and away supporters who have been inconvenienced by the call off at .pm,” it read.“Our ground staff and officials have been in since . this morning and we have been in dialogue with the SPFL since then.“The weather conditions proved extremely dficult to predict with snow, sleet and then rain causing our pitch to ultimately become waterlogged, despite preparatory work being carried out yesterday.”

title: raging staff tell angus council boss to get stuffed over parking issues
story: Council staff have told a senior boss to “get stuffed” after he “told them off” for parking in the streets when their own car parks are packed out by locals avoiding new charges.Staff working for Angus Council in Arbroath have hit out at the message sent out by Mark Armstrong, strategic resources director, which “reminds” workers to use designated staff car parks – which they claim they can never access.Mr Armstrong had been contacted by councillors in the town – who could not be reached for comment – after they received complaints from locals living nearby.Roads around Dewar House and Academy Lane offices have been particularly hard-hit, as they are largely free of parking restrictions.However, workers have criticised the “spineless” email sent by Mr Armstrong because it fails to address what they claim is the real root of the problem – the off-street parking fees introduced by the council last November.One council worker, who declined to be named to protect her job, said Mr Armstrong could “go and get stuffed” over his remarks.She said: “Mark Armstrong seems to think his time is well spent sending an email to staff telling them that they shouldn’t be parking where they are entitled to park.“He can go and get stuffed – we will park where we wish to park. He needs to get a backbone and back off – we are raging.”In his email, Mr Armstrong claims the council is powerless to stop the public from misusing council staff car parks. He wrote: “I understand members of the public are using council staff car parks in Arbroath, possibly in response to parking charges.“Unfortunately there is nothing we can do to deter or prevent this and I appreciate that this may be forcing staff to park where.“Please remind staff to use our car parks wherever possible.”A spokesman for Angus Council said: “Any suggestion this request aims to put pressure on staff is wrong.“We have no intention of enforcing areas where staff, as members of the public themselves, are entitled to park or vice-versa.“It is simply a request for staff to be considerate of residents and to use staff parking wherever possible.”

title: tom duthie dundee united win can put pressure on top dogs ross county
story: Theof winter weather last weekend, and the raft of postponements it led to, has given Dundee United the chance to put some pressure on leaders Ross County when the Championship’s top two clash at Tannadice tonight.First to fall foul of the conditions was County’s Highland derby trip to Inverness Caley Thistle on Friday evening, that one going off because of a waterlogged pitch.Had it gone ahead, it would have provided the Staggies with the opportunity to stretch their advantage over United in the race for automatic promotion to a massive  points.Their own scheduled action at Dunfermline on Saturday afternoon had to be called off after heavy snow and rain left the East End Park playing surface saturated.United had already arrived at the ground and most of their travelling support were not that far away when the call-off was confirmed just  minutes from kick-off.That made it a frustrating afternoon, particularly as it was clear the pitch was in no fit state for a game to be played.But it still means the Tangerines can cut the deficit to their main rivals to eight pointsthey can beat them.With another clash between the pair to come in the Highlands early next month, a victory would leave boss Robbie Neilson still believing his side can finish in top spot in the second tier.To do that United will have to find the form that’s deserted them in recent outings. They’ve managed just one win in four games.And as well as a dip in performance over that period, United have struggled to find the back of the net from open play.In the last five games, only Cammy Smith’s close-range opener in the draw at Falkirk was not from a set-piece and the four other efforts to hit the mark have all been from the boot of Nicky Clark, either from the penalty spot or free-kicks.The effort to improve on that will not be helped by the absence of main striker Pavol Safranko tonight and again when Alloa visit on Saturday, because he is now away on international duty with Slovakia.The other experienced No  in the squad, Osman Sow, would not have been fit for the weekend after aggravating a troublesome calf problem early on in the last outing down at Partick Thistle.Sow was being checked in training yesterday but the chances are he will not make tonight and will even be a major doubt for this weekend.That being the case, Robbie has a big call to make when it comes to how he sets up his attack for the next couple of outings.He does at least have Peter Pawlett back available after the one-game suspension he picked up for his red card in the league win over Inverness. Theof the former Aberdeen man could see Clark pushed right up top and him used in a supporting role.Another option would be to use Matty Smith as the main striker but given the young attacker has not started since the Tannadice win over Dunfermline back on January , that would be a big ask.Whatever way he decides to go, tonight and in the coming games, the boss will be looking for both more chances to be created and a much better conversation rate.That will be a challenge against a County team that have hit league-winning form since mid-January.Their only defeat in  games in all competitions was when they went down to Inverness on penalties in a Scottish Cup replay.

title: brexit thousands in north east sign petition calling for article 50 revoked
story: More than , people in the north-east have signed a petition calling for Article  to be revoked.The petition, which has crashed the UK Government site a number of times already today, has been signed by more than one million people across the country.It calls on parliament to #Revoke Article  and remain in the EU# stating #the Government repeatedly claims exiting the EU is #the will of the people#. We need to put a stop to this claim by proving the strength of public support now, for remaining in the EU. A People#s Vote may not happen # so vote now#.As of .pm today, more than , people in Aberdeen had signed the petition.And in Aberdeenshire around , people have signed.In Moray , and in Angus more than  have signed the petition.Revoke Article  began trending on Twitter following the speech and continued to be a global trend into Thursday morning.Users were quick to share the petition, with celebrities and MPs tweeting their support for Parliament to revoke the Treaty of Lisbon clause that deals with leaving the EU.Famous figures including actors Hugh Grant and Jenner Saunders, TV presenter and author Caitlin Moran, physicist Brian Cox and former Labour press chief Alastair Campbell all urged their followers on social media to sign the petition.Alongside the link, Grant wrote: “I’ve signed. title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. Pupils went close with a headed effort which was clawed to safety while at the other end there was a goalmouth scramble which Star couldn’t convert and both sides had to settle for a draw in the end as referee Jimmy Litster blew for full time.Red Star were dealt a blow as it emerged that captain Aaron Moore suffered a dislocated shoulder. Hopefully this will not keep him out for too long.On Saturday February , Star have another important home game as they look to move off the bottom of the table when they take on Claremont AFC. title: john crawford ardrishaig
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowShinty in Mid Argyll has lost one of its great stalwarts with the passing of John Crawford of Ardrishaig after a short illness.John, aged , died in Mid Argyll Hospital on the evening of Thursday February .John was born and brought up in Minard in Argyll. He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Referees’ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. His work for that competition was recognised by the organisers when he was given a special award at Aviemore along with his friend Donnie MacKenzie of Lochaber.John helped reform Kilmory shinty club in the mid s along with Ian MacPhee, the late Kenny MacRae, Roddy Munro and Alex Campbell. He also served on their committee for many years.John had served as a policeman for a short time before working in the quarry at Furnace, then going on to be a very well-known driver with Gleaner Oils, which supported many of his shinty activities with young players in Argyll.John was a great organiser and acted as goal judge in a number of senior shinty finals including the Glasgow Celtic Society Cup and notably the Camanachd Cup Final in Inverness when Gordon MacIntyre of Oban Camanachd scored his famous winner at the Bught Park.John apparently retrieved the ball from the net and lobbed another onto the park for the re-start before presenting the goal-scoring ball to Gordon after the match.John is survived by his brother Jim who played for Glasgow Police and he was pre-deceased by his we Donella. As a couple they were permanent fixtures at most shinty events in Argyll and well beyond, particularly at events involving young players.Tribute reproduced courtesy of the Camanachd Association

The lights and the clouds change so the painting evolves as you paint.#The painting, Winter Sparkle on Kilbrannan Sound, hanging above the reception desk at the Dochas Centre is the first thing your eye sets on, and keeps you there with a subtle hint of glitter.#That was a bit tongue in cheek,# Ann said. #I didn#t want it to look like a Christmas card. AITC development manager Carron Tobin revealed a collaborative programme of events to promote heritage, food and drink, wildle, events and responsible behaviour around the west coast from Argyll to the Western Isles.Under the banner of #UISGE #, the programme will raise awareness of marine tourism#s stories and develop trails along the west coast.Chris Greenwod of VisitScotland offered insights into tourism trends. #Wellness tourism is growing across the world,# he said. #There is clear potential for this to be incorporated within your products.#It is all about people seeking betterment. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a £, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: gran who hurled bleach over
story: Picture by contracted freelance Steve McKendrick"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA gran who hurled bleach over a child has been granted a personal licence to sell alcohol by East Ayrshire council. Mary McLelland was convicted of throwing the cleaning agent over a -year-old boy’s head and body in Auchinleck. Police objected to McLelland getting a personal licence at the council’s licensing board meeting heard last week, McLelland, , of Main Street, Auchinleck carried out the crime in November . Police Sergeant David Dougan told councillors McLelland was sentenced to a community payback order at Ayr Sherf Court last year as punishment. But McLelland said she was plagued by anti-social behaviour outside at her home in Main Street. She told the board: “I love kids. I regret it.” She claims she has had problems with people “chapping her door” and urinating in her garden. She rushed out to the nearby bus shelter during one incident, she told the meeting.. McLelland said: “I went out. It wasn’t even raw bleach. It is not an excuse. I shouldn’t have done it.” She claimed the bottle was kicked out of her hand and spilled over the victim. But the meeting heard McLelland pled guilty in court. The shop worker said: “I am not in the habit of going out and fighting with kids. “I am a -year-old woman.” She added: “Everybody in this le makes mistakes. Nobody in this world is perfect.” She told the meeting she had phoned the police numerous times to report anti-social behaviour at her property. Councillors adjourned the meeting to discuss whether she should be handed a licence. Ontheir opinion was split with three councillors voting to grant her application and the same number against. Board Chair Councillor Tom Cook had the ruling say and decided to grant McLelland’s licence. He said giving her the licence would not increase her chances of committing a similar offence in the future. Councillors George Mair, John Campbell and Fiona Campbell voted to refuse the licence. Councilors Drew Filson, Lillian Jones supported Councillor Cook’s view to grant it. Councillor Cook said he would grant the licence “albeit with reservations.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnEast Ayrshire CouncilCourtsJusticeAyr

title: people say future high rise
story: NewsPeople to have their say on the future of high-rise flats in AyrTenants asked for their preferred optionShareByGary Fanning:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTenants in the Riverside Place multi-storey flats in Ayr are getting the chance to have their say on the future of the high-rise properties as South Ayrshire Council’s consultation on ‘Your place, your future’ gets underway. The consultation and engagement exercise – approved by Councillors last year – gives tenants the chance to choose their preferred option for the long-term future of the flats: Refurbish  – this means the Council would keep the flats, decant tenants, carry out identied refurbishment works, and thentenants to their refurbished flats. Rehouse  – this means tenants would be rehoused permanently in suitable alternative accommodation and the flats would be demolished. Rebuild  – this means tenants would be decanted to temporary accommodation and the flats would be demolished before some tenantsto a new-build housing development on the Riverside Place site. The detailed consultation, which is based around inidual one-to-one meetings with more than  tenants, has been planned in conjunction with the River Ayr Tenants Association, which represents tenants in the three blocks. The Council has communicated regularly with tenants in the lead-up to the consultation to ensure they have all the information they need to take part. A further letter has now been distributed to homes in Riverside Place following queries and concerns raised by tenants regarding a letter sent to them by Fort, Seafield  Wallacetown Community Council. The community council’s letter appears to query the three consultation options being discussed with tenants and questions South Ayrshire Council’s interpretation of the expert report approved last year regarding the “essential and advisable” works required to the flats. Councillor Philip Saxton, South Ayrshire Council’s Portfolio Holder for Housing and Community Wellbeing, said: “We are committed to ensuring that our tenants are fully involved in the discussions about the future of their flats, which is why we’re taking such a detailed approach to this consultation. “It’s vital that tenants understand all the facts so they can form their own views about the option that is best for them. That is why we have gone back out to them to respond to the queries and confusion that have been generated by the community council’s letter. “We fully appreciate that the community council may have a view on the consultation, which is why colleagues are meeting with them next week and we’re happy to keep them informed about the consultation and engagement process. “However, our focus – which was clearly expressed by tenants at the recent River Ayr Tenants Association meeting – has to be on hearing the views of those who will be directly affected by Councillors’ decisions later this year: the tenants of Riverside Place. “We thank them for their participation in the consultation and I can reassure them that their views will be taken into account before any decisions are taken about the future of Riverside Place.” Joe Lafferty, Chair of the River Ayr Tenants Association, said: “We have worked closely with the Council over the last couple of years as discussions around the future of the flats have moved forward – and we very much appreciate the approach the Council has taken. “It is for every tenant to consider what is the best option for them and to ensure their voice is heard by those who will be making the decisions about what happens next. Clear facts, easy to understand information and answers to the questions tenants have is what’s needed and that’s exactly what we have got from the Council.”   Feedback from the consultation will be considered by Councillors in June this year.Full details of the Riverside Place consultation are available at  www.south-ayrshire.gov.uk riverside-place . title: plans luxury flats prestwicks malcolm
story: NewsPlans for luxury flats at Prestwicks Malcolm Sargent House are scrappedDevelopers have dropped their proposal to build on the famous site at the seafront.ShareByPaul Behan:,  MAR NewsArchitects plans for the retirement flats "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPlans to build luxury flats at the former Malcolm Sargent holiday retreat for sick kids in Prestwick have been binned. The Post can exclusively reveal that the developers McCarthy  Stone have thrown in the towel and withdrawn their multi-million pound proposals. Major question marks hang over the building’s future following the bombshell announcement. The news prompted an angry backlash from Derek Hart, chair of Prestwick North Community Council. In an extraordinary outburst he claimed the building has been “plundered and left to rot.” The building provided a retreat for children battling cancer for more than  years. It was opened by Princess Diana in . In  it was sold by owners Clic Sargent after claims of a “challenging fundraising environment”. They sold it to McCarthy  Stone and trousered £.m from the deal. However, since McCarthy  Stone took ownership and unveiled their luxury flat plans they have been embroiled in a bitter fight with neighbours Prestwick Golf Club. The club was opposed to the development on the basis of its scale and design. Other objections included the potential impact it would have had on their historic course and the surrounding conservation area. In addition, there were fears that errant balls could smash into residents’ properties. Plans involved building  flats for people aged over , spread out in a T-shape over four floors. Many would have had sea views and balconies. The proposals were approved by South Ayrshire Council but last year Prestwick Golf Club successfully petitioned for a judicial review, meaning demolition work on the former retreat had to stop. It was estimated that  jobs would be created between the construction phase and posts at the new development. Despite a PR charm offensive from McCarthy  Stone throughout the process and a public exhibition of plans at the  Club in Prestwick’s Main Street, the developers pulled the plug on the project. A spokesperson said: “Following a strategic review last year we are no longer pursuing any new developments within Scotland and have withdrawn our plans for Prestwick.” Derek Hart reckons the decision is a kick in the teeth for all the campaigners who fought to retain the presence of a sick children’s home in Prestwick. He told the Post: “I find this action taken by McCarthy  Stone not only deplorable but a slap in the face to the Save Malcolm Sargent House team who fought bravely to try to purchase it. “Is it not time for South Ayrshire Council to stop and listen to the community  “The community stated that the development would only feather the nests of McCarthy  Stone – and perhaps chemists –as the age group targeted by them were over  years. “There’s been very little input to Prestwick and we are now left with a building that has been plundered and left to rot. “Will we find the same response to the other end of the beach, at the old Gym, I wonder ”He added: “Time after time SAC have allowed developers to build as they wish with barely a challenge to the character ofthe town and how it should look.”The news will be viewed as a major victory for Prestwick Golf Club, who fought long and hard against the development. A statement by the club said: “While we welcome this news we hope that, should a new development proposal for the site be put forward in the future, the design and scale will be more sympathetic to the surrounding area.” The statement said the club was not against the principle of redeveloping the site but was “disappointed” at the scale and design of the proposed development. It added: “We believed that McCarthy  Stone hadn’t listened to the concerns raised by the club.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnPrincess DianaSouth Ayrshire CouncilRoyal FamilyPrestwickAyr NewsAyr

title: sisters act sibling fiona stricken
story: NewsSisters Act for sibling Fiona, stricken by strokesThousands of pounds raised for Stroke Association by Prestwick pairShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR NewsAfter the race - Gaenor, Gillian and young Graham "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe strokes struck without warning to a lady in her prime. Super-fit Fiona McBlane was , practised yoga and cycled and was in London lapping up a glamorous working le in the music industry for companies such as EMI and Smash Hits. But during a Christmas visit home to Ayrshire she fell unwell with leg, arm and head pain. Such was her distress she admitted herself to hospital. First the minor stroke hit - on January ,  - and then the searing biggie nine days later. It left her semi-paralysed in hospital for  months, unable to speak, hardly walking and retaining very limited brain capacity. That was when Clan McBlane rallied round to give her the best future they could. They had been advised the best place for her was an old folks home but they stood firm. Once Fiona was fit enough to leave hospital she was brought into the bosom of the family in Prestwick. Twelve years on at the age of , Fiona is battling away and has got to the stage where she has joined the gym at Prestwick Tennis Club. Her loving older sisters Gillian McBlane, , and -year-old Gaenor Hardy have just pounded round the Stroke Association’s Resolution Run with Gillian’s -year-old son Graham to continue raising money for the charity. That added £ to a total now of about £. Gillian, a top civil lawyer in Ayr, and Gaenor, headmistress at Heathfield Primary, assist their parents Jean and Ian who are Fiona’s full-time carers. And Gillian is helped by the other legal eagle in the family, Ayr criminal defence agent Steven Maxwell. Gillian said: “She loved her work and was a real high flier. “People were drawn to Fiona’s fun-loving nature and her great big heart. “Never for a minute did we think she would have a stroke. “At  years old she had lost everything she loved.” Fiona is prone to falling and choking, often passing out. Sometimes the enormity of what has happened becomes too much for her and she struggles emotionally. But Gillian said: “Our parents taught us to look for the positive things in le and not to feel sorry for ourselves. We spend time together and Fiona enjoys the company. “Despite the extent of her disability, she does brilliantly. “Doctors told us that her friends would eventually tail off but Fiona’s haven’t . They keep in contact with her and visit when they can. “People have shown us great kindness over the years in so many ways and this means a lot, helping us immensely. We don’t know what the future will hold for Fiona but we do know that whatever it is we will face it together.” There are , strokes in Scotland every year. Angela Macleod at the Stroke Association said: “Our latest research shows that by training and taking part in a Resolution Run you are helping to lower your stroke risk. “The funds raised by each runner means we can reach out to more stroke survivors and their families to offer the support that they may need to rebuild their lives.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnstrokeAyrAyr NewsPrestwickRunningCharity
