title: thought for the week march 15 2019
story: It made me wonder why someone would choose the period of Lent for that purpose. Why not give up something at any timeLent is irrelevant For centuries, Christians have chosen to deny themselves things they enjoy on their journey during Lent. This usually takes the form of chocolate or alcohol or whatever luxury would be sorely missed.It is a time of abstinence and is meant to focus attention on the spiritual journey as we walk the Easter road once again.However it is becoming more popular now to take something on, rather than give something up.People engage in ious activities from committing to write a letter to a prisoner of conscience every day via Amnesty International, to serving in a soup kitchen.There is much we can do in this world. A world in danger from climate change, war, abuse of power, and general disregard for the fragility of the planet.Online petitions flood into our mailboxes every day asking us to sign them for a multitude of worthy causes, and it is dficult to keep up with it all.However maybe we could make a decision this Lent to focus on one of these issues, and make a personal resolution to do something to help.As we think of Jesus taking on the power of the Roman army and the might of the establishment, we know that even one person can make a dference.Yes, that one person was Jesus. But didn#t he promise to send his spirit to be with us – to make a dference

title: letter arran ferry service plea
story: As chair of the Lochranza and Catacol Community Association on the Isle of Arran I have written to the chief executive of Transport Scotland.The association has asked him to revisit the recently rejected proposal for a Lochranza to Claonaig winter ferry service.The association firmly believes that the potential strategic benefits of piloting such a service would, given time, prove highly signicant.Businesses in Arran and Argyll, of all kinds, would benefit greatly, and the through Arran route would open up lines of communication, and closer ties in terms of tourism, transport and infrastructure.The perceived benefits would be felt on Arran, but more so, on the mainland, particularly in Kintyre and Argyll, which have much to gain from an enhanced all year service.It is worth mentioning that this service seems, in terms of weather and technical reliability, to have signicantly better resilience than the Brodick to Ardrossan service.Offering a year-round alternative means of getting on and off the island, particularly in unforeseen circumstances, is in the views of many, not only desirable, but essential.I have copied this letter to other interested parties including the first minister Nicola Sturgeon.Ken Thorburn,

title: hgv apprentice lass is one of mrs blacks boys
story: A former Campbeltown Grammar School girl is leading the way for women as one of two female Argyll and Bute Council vehicle apprentices.Ashleigh Conner, , is described by her ultimate boss, the council#s fleet manager, Sandra Black, , also from Campbeltown and based in the Roading depot, as a #mini-me.#Across the top of all the garage#s Campbeltown computer screens is a label the apprentice mechanics have made up, which states: #Mrs Black#s Boys and Girl.#Ashleigh has always taken a keen interest in all things mechanical and is following in her father David Conner#s footsteps. He is Kintyre Recycling Ltd#s transport manager and is based next door in Glebe Street.Last week Ashleigh, who recently passed her heavy goods vehicle test, joined Mrs Black to give S presentations, about apprenticeships at the Grammar School.Before the talks Ashleigh, who is also a retained fire fighter and is sometimes seen driving a fire tender in town, said: #I worked in C-op for a year before starting the four-year apprenticeship with the council in November .#In th year at school I had taken an engineering course with Argyll College and I loved every minute.#Every day I am buzzing and never think in the morning: #Oh no! I don#t want to go to work.##In Campbeltown there are at least  vehicles to service including minibuses, bin lorries and trucks.#In addition one day a week I have to get up early to catch the first ferry from Kennacraig to go to Islay where the council maintains a fleet of vehicles.#Mrs Black added: #The council has  mechanics and vehicle depots on its islands as well as in Lochgilphead, Dunoon, Helensburgh and Oban.#Things were very dferent when Mrs Black left school and she said: #My father, a farmer, passed away when I was  and my le changed.#I first worked as a catering assistant and subsequently worked  years in catering before taking part in an Argyll and Bute Council scheme called #Grow Your Own#.#It was similar to an apprenticeship but for older people who the council wanted to develop.#In addition to the many qualications, taken at night school, for her current role, Mrs Black holds a certicate of professional competence in national and international haulage.Ashleigh is also learning the theory of vehicle maintenance and once every six weeks attends block release courses in Glasgow.There she joins the council#s other female vehicle apprentice, Kelly Crawford, from Lochgilphead and nine lads at GTG Training.It is the first time GTG, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Arnold Clark, has taken female apprentices but Ashleigh says: #We don#t get treated any dferently to the boys and so far I have passed everything.#There is lots of additional study needed outside the classroom.#It is very technical at college and much more in-depth, for instance we might learn about how an air brake works.#At work we know a part is broken or needs fixing and that is what we mend.#Chargehand mechanic Michael Renton supervises all tasks allocated to Ashleigh.Mr Renton said: #Ashleigh is very capable at everything. Sometimes we have people on work experience who say they don#t want to do some things.#Ashleigh added: #No one thing is my favourite, it is all interesting and every day is dferent.#On my very first day I had to get into the back of a bin lorry because the sensors were faulty.#Giving advice to S pupils Ashleigh said: #It is always best to go for what you want, you can only try.#I think it is better to do something than just go to college without the practical basis.#As an apprentice you have the benefit of being paid while learning.#You could end up in the same or a better place than someone who has been to college.#Argyll and Bute Council HGV mechanical apprentice Ashleigh Conner, , checks a truck wheel from the garage pit. _capprentice_Ashleigh_ConnerChecking a truck#s tyre pressures. _capprentice_Ashleigh_ConnerAshleigh torques up wheel nuts. _capprentice_Ashleigh_ConnerAshleigh Conner in a truck#s driving seat. _capprentice_Ashleigh_ConnerThe sign on all Argyll and Bute#s fleet computers. _capprentice_Ashleigh_Conner

title: breathing-space-for-the-hollies-day-centre-after-120000-boost
story: The grant, for a three-year period, has been announced, much to the delight of manager Liz Shannon.She told the Courier: ldquoThe dference the award from The National Lottery Community Fund will make to the members and customers of the Hollies is immeasurable.ldquoIt will give a breathing space for the near future.ldquoIt will allow us to not only maintain existing services but expand what we already offer the elderly population of Musselburgh and surrounding areas.ldquoThis includes providing entertaining and structured activities for the over-s in a warm, safe and comfortable environment.ldquoWe also want to help prevent social isolation and encourage social interaction by continuing to provide a place for people to meet friends and make new ones.Maureen McGinn, chairperson of The National Lottery Community Fund Scotland, said: ldquoI am delighted that Hollies Day Centre SCIO has been successful in securing a grant from The National Lottery Community Fund.ldquoThe award will make a big dference where it is needed most and I wish the Hollies Day Centre every success as it goes on to develop and expand its project for the benefit of their local community.Ms Shannon said that the lottery funding would help with services such as staffing costs and the centre would also continue to fundraise.The good news follows a dficult time for the cash-strapped Hollies, which was the victim of a break-in before Christmas when a safe was stolen from the High Street premises.But supporters and members of the public rallied round, with donations from ious sources, including Scott Glynn of the Tranent-based Walk with Scott Foundation, who presented a cheque to the centre for pound, to replace the cash stolen in the safe.Staff and volunteers also celebrated the success of their pound, bid for funding from the Robertson Trust, which aids organisations working in Scotland and a pound, leline from the Musselburgh Common Good Fund to keep its services going in the lead-up to Christmas.The Hollies, which received an pound, grant from East Lothian Council last year, has received its final instalment of more than pound, which takes it to the end of the financial year in March.Ms Shannon said that the centre was still in talks with the local authority over provision of its services in the future.Martin Whitfield, East Lothian MP, visited the Hollies recently to meet staff, volunteers and members, and congratulate them on their lottery funding boost.He said: ldquoThe Hollies Day Centre is a much-loved community facility which does an amazing job for older people in Musselburgh.ldquoI was pleased to visit the centre to meet staff, volunteers and some of the local people who use its services and congratulate them on their latest success in securing this lottery funding.ldquoItrsquos great news for the centre and will help it to keep making a positive dference for older people in Musselburgh.ldquoI want to congratulate Liz and her team, and thank them for everything they do.Ms Shannon added: ldquoThe Hollies staff and volunteers were delighted to welcome Mr Whitfield.ldquoHe enjoyed a tour of our fabulous community resource in the centre of Musselburgh.ldquoWe hope that he will visit again soon so we can keep him abreast of all the new and exciting activities taking place at the Hollies.

title: top-jockey-peter-scudamore-helps-launch-new-replay-cards-at-musselburgh-racecourse
story: On-hand to support the initiative last week was eight-time champion jockey Peter Scudamore MBE and local MP Martin Whitfield.Mr Scudamore joined local Sporting Memories groups, volunteers and other local racing representatives to talk about his time as a jockey and trainer and share his memories and stories. He also took part in a question-and-answer session involving group members.The launch at Musselburgh, Scotlandrsquos second biggest racecourse, was held by Sporting Memories in partnership with Racing Welfare Scotland and Racing Together. It ran simultaneously with another launch event at Palace House, The National Heritage Centre for Horseracing  Sporting Art, at Newmarket.The sporting aid memory cards feature the great and the good of horseracing throughout history and were compiled with the assistance of Racing Welfarersquos Malton-based welfare team to support older people living with dementia, depression and loneliness. The cards have an image of a sporting legend on the front and some information about their achievements on the back.Sporting Memories produces a number of resources and materials to inspire and promote reminiscence, which are then available for third-party organisations to buy to utilise at their own events.Chris Wilkins, co-founder and director of Sporting Memories Network, said: ldquoThe Sporting Memories Foundation in England and Scotland uses sports reminiscence to engage isolated older people living with conditions such as dementia, loneliness and depression.ldquoOur club members, who meet on a weekly basis in locations across the UK, are brought together through a shared love of sport, and enjoy using our replay reminiscence cards that help trigger memories and conversation.ldquoWe have already produced a range of replay cards which reflect a wide selection of sports, and we are now delighted to launch our latest set on racing, which will help to trigger memories of watching or participating in horseracing.ldquoThemes for the cards were suggested by members of our Racing Welfare Sporting Memories Club at Malton and reflect some of the great jockeys, horses and courses that together represent some of the best and most enduring memories of racing.ldquoImages can be very powerful in helping prompt memories and stories which, particularly for people living with dementia, can otherwise remain locked away and untold. Our aim is to unlock those stories and together celebrate some wonderful racing memories.ldquoWe couldnrsquot deliver our work without the support of volunteers and we are always looking for other sports fans who might be interested in supporting the fun and fulfilling activities that take place in our weekly clubs. Information about our clubs and volunteering opportunities can be found at our website thesmfMP Mr Whitfield said: ldquoI was delighted to attend the launch of the Sporting Memories Foundationrsquos new racing replay cards in Musselburgh.ldquoThese cards are another great resource from Sporting Memories, which has an extensive range of sporting memory aids. Listening to Peterrsquos stories and the memories they evoked in others made it clear what a valuable tool they can be for those living with dementia.ldquoI commend Sporting Memories and Racing Welfare on this welcome initiative and their other activity supporting older and vulnerable people.

title: east-lothian-council-services-for-hire
story: The council is looking at ways to bring in extra revenue in the next three years by capitalising on its services and the influx of new housing in the county.Burial plots in two new cemeteries will be made available for advance sales as the council re-opens the pre-sale of lairs in Dunbar and Prestonpans, where capacity issues have seen the practice suspended in recent years. New housing developments in the towns have seen plans put forward for new graveyards to cope with the increasing populations.In Prestonpans, a proposed cemetery is included with plans to build  houses at Dolphingstone Farm while in Dunbar plans for a new graveyard at Newtonlees have been approved by the council.A council spokesperson said advance sales were withdrawn in the towns to ensure lairs were available for immediate need as they ran out of space.However, he confirmed: ldquoIt is expected that, as the new provision opens in Prestonpans and Dunbar, we will be in a position to process requests.As further new sites are developed, it is anticipated this option will become more widely available.It is anticipated the move will bring an additional pound, in revenue for the local authority in the next financial year as people queue up to book plots in their home towns.The move is one of a number of ventures which have been given the go-ahead in the councilrsquos budget plans for the next three years to maximise income.It also includes plans to bid to take over factoring contracts for landscaping in new housing developments and offer to install play equipment and areas in the same estates.The local authority is looking to capitalise on the influx of housing into the county, which is seeing up to , new homes being built across its communities.It hopes that it can compete with private factoring firms to take on responsibility for public areas within new housing estates, which developers traditionally hand on to independent factors.And it has budgeted a potential income of up to pound, by providing the commercial service over the next three years, as well as a further pound, by offering to install play areas in the new developments.The council said it was seeking to develop ldquocommercial opportunities across all services.The spokesman said: ldquoGiven the countyrsquos growth agenda, these are areas that we intend to explore.

title: man-who-slept-in-van-after-drinking-avoids-driving-ban
story: Mario Delacruz, , was caught sleeping in his van in an Edinburgh car park after he had been out drinking with friends in the city last year.Delacruz was spotted by police officers sleeping in the passenger seat of his van but they also saw his keys were lying nearby on the driverrsquos seat.The officers woke the Spanish national up and, after noticing he had been drinking alcohol, decided to breathalyse him.The tests showed that Delacruz, of The Promenade, was more than four times the drink-drive limit.Delacruz appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court, where he pleaded guilty to being in charge of the vehicle at the time on October  last year.Solicitor Peter OrsquoNeill said that his client had been out with friends in the Leith area of the city and had decided to ldquosleep it off before going home the following day.Mr OrsquoNeill said that Delacruz had been in the UK for about five years and had moved to Scotland last July.He currently works as a cleaner and has sold the van he was found sleeping in.The lawyer added: ldquoHe is sorry and knows it should not have happened.Sherf John Cook fined Delacruz pound and told him that he would have  penalty points placed on his licence.Delacruz pleaded guilty to being in charge of a motor vehicle with mcg of alcohol in ml of breath at Nichollfield, Edinburgh, on October  last year. The legal limit is  mcg.

title: port-seton-man-offers-to-clean-gardens-of-dog-waste
story: Super Pet Scooper was founded in January by Port Seton man Greg Mahony, of Laburnum Avenue, who will be servicing the East Lothian area for its doggy clear-up needs.ldquoI was looking for a business opportunity in the area, Greg said.ldquoCleaning gardens of dog waste is big in the USA and Canada, and even England, but not around here, so I saw a gap in the marketOriginally from Manchester, Greg and his family fell in love with all East Lothian had to offer, especially when walking his own rescue dog, Rocco. It was then he noticed that dog fouling in the area was becoming an issue.ldquoOur community wants to live in a nice environment, he said.ldquoWe promote responsible ownership, enforce fines and put up signs, but sometimes itrsquos just not enough.ldquoMany dog owners, like myself, always take doggie bags to clean up the waste, but sadly, many owners do not.This was when Greg came up with the idea for Super Pet Scooper.ldquoI never thought Irsquod start a business, but I wanted to do something that would help people and I love animals, especially dogs, so it made sense, he said.ldquoI donrsquot mind cleaning up after dogs, it doesnrsquot bother me! It also gets me out and about on a weekend, as well as a little more income.Greg works during the week for the NHS but has high hopes that he can build his company to a full-time role.ldquoAt the moment, Irsquom only part-time but Irsquom hoping to expand, he said.ldquoI got in touch with East Lothian Council for advice and they were fantastic, helped me get my waste carrier licence and advice on business insurance and things.Despite only being in his first month of business, the -year-old has a few clients and has been getting good reviews across Facebook.ldquoIrsquove had a positive reaction to the company, he said. ldquoI know a lot of people think thatyou have a dog you should be able to clean up after them yourself, but a lot of people canrsquot. They can fall ill or just become unable to move around like they used to, so thatrsquos where I can help.

title: pictures-a-look-around-the-new-wallyford-primary-school
story: The move to the new pound.million Wallyford Primary School took place on February .Mhairi Stratton, headteacher, said: ldquoIrsquove been really impressed at how quickly the children have settled into their new school. Theyrsquore enjoying the outdoor space and the freedom it gives them.ldquoThe more open classroom layouts are also great and very flexible for learning and play.As pupils settle into the new school, which boasts  classrooms and a further four nursery playrooms, East Lothian Council is in the process of securing land for a second high school for the Musselburgh area.The approval of the new high school, which will be built on land near Dolphingstone and take in students from the Pinkie area of Musselburgh, as well as Wallyford, was given at a meeting of East Lothian Council in December .The new high school was expected to begin taking in pupils from August , or as soon as possible after that date.But the council then wrote to all concerned to tell them that the expected opening of the school had now been put back to August .The decision to build a new secondary school near Wallyford followed a public consultation after it became clear that Musselburgh Grammar School would not be able to cope with the expected influx of new residents as a result of extensive housebuilding in Musselburgh and Wallyford.Three options were put forward: extend the current Grammar building create an upper and lower school on two campuses or build a new secondary school to complement Musselburgh Grammar.The council said a clear majority was in favour of building a new school but some labelled the consultation ldquoflawed.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe are in the process of securing the land for a new secondary provision for the Musselburgh area. Our capital budget for the five-year period  -  has allocated pound.m towards the project and developer contributions will be secured towards this investment.No decision has been taken on the future of the former Wallyford Primary School building at Salters Road, which was too small to accommodate the rising population.Land was secured on the east side of the town on the St Clementrsquos Wells development to create a new primary school campus to offer room for modern educational facilities for a growing school population, surrounded by plenty of outdoor space.The council spokesperson said: ldquoNow that the new Wallyford Primary School is open and ing, we are in the final stages of moving equipment from the old school.ldquoNo decision has been taken on the future of the former school site but the council will be considering options.

title: search-for-headteacher-for-new-merged-prestonpans-primary-school
story: That comes after it was confirmed that the current headteachers of both schools would not be putting their names forward for the role.East Lothian Council approved a merger of the two schools last December.The local authority has now confirmed that neither the current headteacher of Prestonpans Primary, Jonathan Revell, nor of Prestonpans Infant School, Sheila Laing, will be applying for the role.Sheila Laing became headteacher at Prestonpans Infant School in September , moving from Campie Primary School in Musselburgh, while Mr Revell was appointed headteacher at Prestonpans Primary in September .A video has been posted on Prestonpans Primary Schoolrsquos Twitter feed and its parent council Facebook page in which pupils and teachers appeal for candidates to apply.In the video, Fiona Robertson, head of education at the council, states the need for someone who can ldquobelieve, achieve, strive for excellence and care for all.The video also sees the children demonstrate their cooking and sign language skills, with one child adding: ldquoThe best teachers you could ever wish for are in this school.ldquoThere are lots of fun and dferent events happening throughout the year.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet member for education, told the Courier: ldquoThis is a great opportunity for someone who is passionate about supporting an amazing school and its local community.ldquoThere is already lots of great work happening in Prestonpans, especially in supporting and engaging with parents and carers, which has received national recognition. We need someone who will continue to build upon this work and support our children and young people to achieve their fullest potential.The appeal for the new headteacher coincides with a consultation that has been opened by the council to give a name to the new school.The name of the school, as suggested by the council, should be based on either a notable person from the area, the location of the school or include the vision of the school.The consultation closes on March , and any suggestions can be either emailed to educationconsultations@eastlothian.gov.uk or posted to John Muir House, Haddington.The new school will follow a single curriculum. There are no plans to move buildings, with the new school running across the two former education establishments.

title: plans-lodged-to-turn-former-dunbar-rbs-into-a-sweet-shop
story: Gavin and Susan Love, of Love Sweets and Ices, plan to open a second sweet shop on Dunbar High Street, with a shop within the former Royal Bank of Scotlandpremises.The national bank moved out of  High Street last May, with the premises lying empty ever since.Now plans have been submitted to East Lothian Council looking for alterations to be carried out and the building to be turned into a shop and cafe with outdoor seating.Drawings included in the planning application show little in the way of changes inside the building, with internal walls remaining in place.A seating area would be included at the rear of the building, with benches outside the front in a fenced-off seating area.A managerrsquos office would also be created to the front of the building.Gavin Love, who along with we Susan runs the business at its existing premises of  High Street, said: ldquoThings have been progressing really well.ldquoOur initial plan was to open in March but we have now decided to add some internal seating for sit-in ice cream and we now intend to open in late April early May.Mr and Mrs Love intend to run both shops and use the additional space to provide a wider range of traditional specialised confectionery products and ice cream.Drawings included within the planning application suggest a new lsquoThe Sweetie Bankrsquo sign could be created outside the business.The plans were first highlighted at the townrsquos community council meeting in November last year.Pippa Swan, the grouprsquos chairwoman, was hopeful the business would prove to be a great success.She said: ldquoI had no idea there was such a demand for sweeties and scrumptious things but what a wonderful, fun use of a great building. Irsquom looking forward to it and I am sure it will be a good addition to the street.The bank branch closure was one of  RBS and  NatWest branches to shut following a decision at the end of .The move was widely criticised by local politicians and members of the public, with North Berwickrsquos RBS also closing.

title: belhaven-bays-baywatch-to-patrol-the-beach-this-summer
story: A grant of pound, has been given to Dunbar Surf Le Saving Clubto run the project, which will see training given to volunteers, as well as raising awareness of the risks associated with the coast.The money, from the Big Lottery Fund, will ensure the Dunbar organisation is the first of its kind in Scotland to run a volunteer Beach Surf Lesaving Patrol.Sally Harris, head coach of DSLSC, told the Courier: ldquoWe are absolutely delighted to receive this funding from the National Lottery.ldquoWe will now be able to put together Scotlandrsquos first community-led voluntary surf lesaving beach patrol team in Dunbar.ldquoThe funding will also allow us to continue our preventative education programme, helping to reduce the national coastal drowning statistics.The aims of the Belhaven Bay Community Le Saving Beach Patrol are to provide a lesaving service for the community and visitors, to prevent accidental drowning and injury among beach users.Training will also be given to young people and adults in the community to deliver the services while also raising awareness of the risks associated with using the beach and sea.In , more than  people drowned in the UK.Belhaven Bay, Scotlandrsquos first volunteer Beach Patrol Service are going to start this year.ldquoI would like to congratulate them on their successful application to the Big Lottery.ldquoThis will provide some title: world-champion-sprinter-maria-lyle-thanks-her-mum-for-rekindling-her-love-of-athletics
story: Maria Lyle ed from the Fazza International Championships in Dubai recently with two gold medals.However, it was just last year that she broke down in tears during her ldquodarkest moment before a major competition.The teenager has lived with diplegic cerebral palsy in her legs almost all her le.The -year-old told the Courier that her mum Susan had been with her throughout her journey, which has seen her represent Great Britain in the Paralympics and Scotland in the Commonwealth Games.Her mum is a PE teacher at Dunbar Primary School and taught Maria.Keen for Maria to be involved as much as her peers, but with little experience of teaching pupils with a disability, Susan looked for ways to deliver lessons which allowed Maria to flourish.Maria said: ldquoWhen I was younger, I struggled quite a lot. Things didnrsquot come quite as naturally for me as they did for my peers and often I ended up feeling a bit rubbish about myself.ldquoThings drastically changed, however, after one PE lesson. We had to complete the multi-stage fitness test .ldquoAs someone who fell over constantly and ended up with cut knees  per cent of the time, you could say I wasnrsquot that keen to join the lesson.ldquoTo everyonersquos surprise, I was the last one left in the test. That was the first time Irsquod ever felt such a sense of achievement. From that moment, running would become a big part of my le.Those short runs started to build Mariarsquos strength.She became European champion in  and within the next four years Paralympic, World and Commonwealth medals followed.But despite all her success, Maria couldnrsquot find the same love for her sport as she had during those early runs with her mum. The teenager became overwhelmed with worry about competing and her concerns impacted her le away from the track.After suffering in silence for years, Maria finally opened up to her mum, who convinced her to seek professional help. She was later diagnosed with having anxiety.Maria, who works at the Scottish Parliament as a committee assistant, said: ldquoMy mum would give up lots of her time, she would lead my sessions and drive me all over the country so I could compete. She would even take time off work to watch me in competitions. Because of this I would get worriedI didnrsquot run well.ldquoIrsquod feel guilty about wasting her time. Disappointing my mum wasnrsquot the only thing I was anxious about. I was worried about my competitors and factors I couldnrsquot control.ldquoBefore the  European Championships, I revealed something to my mum that I had never spoken about before. I broke down and cried for hours expressing how rubbish I felt about myself in both my running and personal le.ldquoRunning had completely taken over and there was nothing positive.ldquoIn my darkest moment, my mum was there for me.ldquoShe was the one who listened for hours. She was the one who hugged me. From that day, my mum and my immediate family have supported me. They have made me realise that there is more to le than running.Susan said that no medal ceremony could compare to seeing her daughter enjoying running again. She said: ldquoMy proudest moment is not Maria winning medals on the world stage, it is probably Maria competing in Glasgow last weekend at the  National Indoor Championships.ldquoFor the first time in years, I saw Maria stand on the start line feeling relaxed and running through the finish line with a smile on her face.ldquoAlong with the support from us as a family and her coach, Jamie Bowie, Maria has turned herself around and is back on track in all areas of her le.

title: meeting-arranged-in-bid-to-save-cockenzie-and-port-seton-gala
story: Organisers previously announced following their emergency general meetingyesterday eveningthat the gala, which celebrated its th anniversary last year,had been cancelled due to a lack of support.A statement issued on Facebook by Cockenzie and Port Seton Gala committee said:"Following on from the poor attendance at our EGM, it is with deep regret that we must inform you that the  gala is cancelled and future galas are also in jeopardy."We appreciate this will be deeply upsetting for you all to hear."We will look to organise a disco event for the gala children as a small compensation."We tried our best but we can no longer carry on with the number of committee we have."However,after an outpouring of support on Facebook, the committee has decided to review the decision to cancel the gala, although its future is still uncertain.A meeting will be held on Thursdayand all volunteers and potential committee members are encouraged to attend.The meeting takesplace at pm at Port Seton Community Centre cafe, with any queries to be emailedto cpsgala@hotmail

title: developer-looks-to-have-plans-rubber-stamped-for-another-150-houses-in-gullane
story: CALA Homes already has planning permission in principle for the site at Saltcoats Field, on the villagersquos south-eastern edge.Now they will look for the local authority to approve the villas.Registered Social Landlord People for Places will also provide  affordable properties.That will be made up of eight one-bedroom apartments and a dozen two-bedroom apartments.Ten two-bedroom semi-detached properties will also be created, alongside eight three-bedroom semi-detached homes.Tom Drysdale, chairman of the villagersquos community council, which also covers Dirleton, Aberlady, West Fenton and Drem, said: ldquoPlanning permission in principle was given some time ago.ldquoWhat they have applied for is detailed planning permission.ldquoWe have been looking at that, the houses, with two cars, and people are simply going to use their cars.ldquoThat was the area we have written in, making those comments, and hope the council will take on board.According to the developer, the proposals will help to meet the growing need for new family homes in the local area, with the properties appealing to a erse range of buyers.The development will also see CALA invest a further pound.m into local infrastructure, including schools, transport, sports pitches, play equipment and rail contributions.Other proposals by CALA include a footway from Gullane to West Fenton, Gullane.ldquoSubject to the planning process, we hope to be in position to commence development in , with homes for sale being available in .

title: labour-and-liberal-democrats-announce-haddington-by-election-candidates
story: The vice-chairman of Ormiston Community Council has been announced as Labourrsquos candidate for the seat vacated by the resignation of Conservative councillor Brian Small last month.Neal Black to contest this important election.ldquoI can think of no greater honour than being able to serve the community where I was born and have lived my whole le.ldquoIrsquom looking forward to giving my title: council-paying-20-per-cent-over-valuation-for-new-sheltered-housing-in-tranent
story: The new development in Tranent will see four one-bedroom and eight two-bedroom flats bought by the local authority for pound.million.Planning chiefs said that the decision to pay above the district valuerrsquos recommended value of pound.million was taken because they believed it was good value for money.And they argued it was hard to value the new properties correctly as there were no other homes like them in the town.The flats, being built on the site of a former dairy on Elder Street in the town centre, will be bought by the council once complete.A report on the purchase, which has been agreed by the council with the local developer, said that although they were designated as sheltered housing, no warden accommodationor common room was included on the site.It said: ldquoWhilst these properties will be restricted to specialist housing, discussions are currently being held as the preferred client group. This may result in the designation being changed from sheltered housing in the future.The report revealed that the final purchase price for the flats, which will include a lt and sprinkler system, was above the district valuerrsquos valuation of the propertyrsquos worth by some pound,.However, planning chiefs said there was evidence that the development represented value for money. The report adds: ldquoThe valuation of these flats in Tranent is dficult as there are no other similar flats for sale in the area to make a comparison with and consequently may be under-valued.The flats will be added to the councilrsquos rental stock once available.

title: tims-tales-johnnie-copes-journey
story: I WAS in Lauder last weekend to tell stories to the Lauder Cub Group.It was at the invitation of old friends whose son attends the Cubs there, and afterwards we spent a lovely evening catching up and being amazed how our respective children had grown so much since wersquod last seen each other.My friends had previously lived in Prestonpans, and as the evening wore on there was talk about the memories from their time there, where I still stay.Soon after my friends arrived in Lauder, they discovered a plaque which commemorated the arrival of Johnnie Cope in . Lauder, it is said, was the first place he stopped after fleeing from the Battle of Prestonpans.ldquoI suppose we kind of followed in his footsteps, said my friend, ldquoalthough in a very dferent way and totally dferent circumstances of course. Folk round here donrsquot really know the story, but coming from the Pans it gave us an immediate connection.The actual house on Lauder High Street that Johnnie Cope arrived at is now gone, replaced over  years ago. But Lauder must look much as it did on that fateful day when Cope arrived, with his horse close to collapse with exhaustion.Johnnie Cope was the general commanding the British Army at Prestonpans on that fateful day, September , . The battle was a major victory for the Jacobites. Cope fled the scene of battle, but only when it was clearly lost. He eventually arrived at Berwick-upon-Tweed to give news of his own defeat. Ever since, popular tradition has mocked Cope for running away and not standing his ground and dying lsquohonourablyrsquo, as Colonel Gardiner of Bankton House did.This ridicule was encapsulated in a traditional popular song, and the chorus remains well-known:Hey, Johnnie Cope, are ye wauking yet Or are your drums a-beating yet If ye were wauking I wad waitTae gang to the coals irsquo the morning.The song pokes fun at Cope and concludes with a harsh indictment:Now Johnnie, troth, ye were na blateTae come wirsquo news orsquo your ain defeat,And leave your men in sic a straitSae early in the morning.There are earlier versions with slightly dferent words, but the sentiment remains the same: Johnnie Cope ran away and should be ashamed of himself for leaving his men. However, he was later found to have done his duty, and this reputation deemed unfair. But mud sticks, especially when a catchy tune is added to it.This popular song is believed to have been written by Adam Skirving, a farmer at Garleton in East Lothian. There is a story that he visited the battle site a few hours after the fighting. Perhaps he spoke to some eyewitnesses who saw Cope flee up the road to Birsley Brae, and therefore got the idea for the song. The road Cope took as he fled from the battle has ever after been called Johnnie Copersquos Road.Lauder is a short journey from Prestonpansgoing by car. It had been a while since I had last ventured over Soutra Hill and into the border country and I enjoyed the drive despite the wild weather, or perhaps partly because of it.But what was Copersquos journey like as he galloped over Soutra Hill with some of his dragoons  He must have paused at the summit and cast a glance at the view over East Lothian and screwed his eyes to find Prestonpans. The panic and terror by this time would have given way to dferent feelings, I suspect.He rode more or less the same way I took to Lauder but it would have taken him much longer with very dferent emotions. His arrival in the town would have been a bewildering spectacle for the locals. He later continued his flight to Coldstream, which he reached by nightfall.All this was in my head as we headed home to Prestonpans from Lauder the next day. I could almost see the ghosts of Cope and his dragoons gallop past us as we ventured over Soutra.As we drove, I re-told the story to my kids and we sang the song in the car. They know the story and the chorus well, as we have many times ventured along Johnnie Cope Road on the way to the rail station.By the road is Bankton House, once the home of Colonel Gardiner, who did not run but stood his ground, and paid the ultimate price with brutal death.There is a small doorsquocot by the house, and inside you will find a free but almost secret visitor centre created with the support of the Battle of Prestonpans Heritage Trust.The doorsquocot can only be reached via a walkway through the wood from the rail station during the day, and inside lsquoAuld Archiersquo tells the tale of the battle, and the le and death of Colonel Gardiner. On the wall is a model map of how the area looked at the time of the battle, with the route taken by Johnnie Cope clearly marked.Itrsquos all fascinating stuff which had been unexpectedly brought to my mind by the visit to Lauder to see old friends.But it was the emotions rather than the events that I reflected on most. The hatred caused by this civil war , the loss, suffering and misery of conflict which is so often hidden by a cloak of romanticism.Adam Watters, a Panner who lives and breathes local history, and re-enacts it for children and visitors alike, is clear on this. It is a fascinating period to study, and to have the history on our doorstep brings it alive. But as Adam has said, letrsquos enjoy that sense of history on our doorstep and have fun with it, but let us not glory battle, rather learn from it.I think Johnnie Cope, even though he was a military man, may well have agreed with Adam.

title: east-lothian-council-cockenzie-revised-plan
story: Inch Cape Offshore Ltd has been given approval to site the building ndash which will bring energy ashore from an offshore wind farm ndash on land at the former Cockenzie Power Station by Scottish Ministers.A planning application was initially lodged with East Lothian Council but was called in by the Scottish Government before a decision was made.That decision sparked anger after it was announced as First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was on an official visit to China, where she met representatives of Chinese state owned Red Rock, which owns Inch Cape.Now the company has presented a revised plan of the space it intends to use to Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council.The community council posted the new design on social media and revealed plans were under way for Inch Cape to host workshops in the local communities in the coming months.The image shows the substation on about a third of the original .-hectare footprint applied for.One of the biggest concerns raised by communities and the local authority, which owns the land, was that a substation dominating the old power station site would make it a no-go area for other developments.The new plans were welcomed by many on the community councilrsquos Facebook page, with one person saying: ldquoGood news, less sterilisation of the site.Ian Johnson, Inch Capersquos project manager, said: ldquoWe are continuing to engage with East Lothian Council and local community councils on options to signicantly reduce the footprint of the onshore transmission works and moving this to the west of the site.ldquoWhile this detailed design plan is subject to further technical assessments, consultation and approval from the council, we are taking steps to ensure remaining land is available for other developments.

title: east-lothian-school-pupils-to-take-part-in-strike-against-climate-change
story: The NBHS Eco Committee have encouraged students to travel by public transport to attend the rally campaigning for stronger government action to combat climate change.The Edinburgh protest is one of many around the world that are happening tomorrow morning, where school children are walking out of classes to protest climate change.The protest starts at am outside the Scottish Parliament.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe want to support our young people as global citizens to have their voice and to be able to express their views on important matters such as climate change."The safety and wellbeing of our young people is of paramount importance to us. We would therefore ask that any young person who wishes to attend this event first discusses it with their parent or carer before notying the headteacher of the intention to be absent from school on this date."Given that the young person will not be on school premises at this time, and therefore not the responsibility of school staff, they will be marked as having had an unauthorised absence.

title: three-hour-jumpathon-for-red-nose-day-at-musselburgh-trampoline-park
story: The team at Jump In in Newhailes Industrial Estate will need to have a real spring in their step when they don their pyjamas to take part in a national -hour Jumpathon relay with the companyrsquos seven other UK sites.Theyrsquore inviting more jumpers to join them for their three-hour session in aid of Comic Relief between pm and pm tomorrow .There will be the chance to donate on the day or those who canrsquot attend but would still like to show their support can visit justgiving fundraising jump-inGareth Trail, regional manager for Jump In, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be involved in Red Nose Day, raising money for so many special causes.ldquoWe would love to see as many people as possible down here on the day showing their support to our staff, who will be jumping for three hours non-stop.Other attractions on the day will include face-painting, a cake sale and raffle with a hamper full of Jump In goodies up for grabs.

title: cockenzie-and-port-seton-gala-saved
story: The galas organising committee had announced on Monday evening that this years gala had been cancelled due to a lack of volunteers.But an outpouring of support on social media caused an emergency meeting to be held yesterday eveningto consider the future of the gala.And following that meeting, the gala committee posted on Facebook: ldquoWe would like to give a big thank you to all who attended the EGMtonight."We are thrilled to announce that we are now in a position to go ahead with the  gala.Full steam ahead!Cockenzie and Port Seton Gala celebrated its th anniversary last year and is one of the largest galas in East Lothian.

title: tranents-redeveloped-former-co-op-building-getting-ready-to-re-open
story: The building on Winton Place is being converted into a Post Office, convenience store and coffee shop by well-known local couple George and SusanThomson.ldquoWe want to expand the business but we also want a nice place for people in the community to go and socialise, said George. ldquoWe want to draw people to the High Street.ldquoWersquove ran the Post Office in Tranent for over  years now, added Susan. ldquoWersquore really involved with the community, so this project was important to us in so many ways.As well as being postmaster, Susanco-founded the Blooming Belters and is the secretary of the townrsquos gala committee.ldquoAlthough wersquore converting a lot of it, it will still be able to host the local groups and charities that make this community so special, she said.The Thomsons worked closely with Historic Scotland to ensure that the Edwardian building retained its original charm, including putting in stained glass windows around the outside of the structure.George said: ldquoThe stained glass windows help make the building look how it would have looked a hundred years ago.ldquoHistoric Environment Scotland had also asked to have a temporary exhibition about the history of shopfronts in the country over the last  years, and there was so much interest in it that wersquove made it into a permanent display.The impressive window display covers all styles of shopfronts in Scotland throughout the century, giving information on the dferent materials used, accompanied by an archive of photos of shops dating back to the late s.ldquoThe work wersquove done with Historic Scotland is a perfect example of a public and private partnership that can maintain and renovate listed buildings, George said.The plans for the building have been in the making since  and Susanrecalled the highs and lows of taking on such project.ldquoItrsquos great finally seeing it all come together, she said. ldquoAt the start itrsquos dficult to see what it will look like and, of course, itrsquos a lot of work. Wersquore excited for it to be open and for people to get to see the finished product. We think itrsquoll be pretty special, especially in the summer when we get the chairs outside and all the flowers are in bloom.The opening in April will mark the end of phase one for the Thomsons.Phase two will involve creating a soft play area and flats above the shop, as well as a community hall.The work on phase two will begin in August, with hopes that the whole project will be completed by .

title: giant-bear-statue-could-be-in-place-near-dunbar-next-month
story: Permission for the ft-tall bear was finally given in October last year, with the work of art set to be in place in the spring.Renowned Scottish artist Andy Scott, responsible for the Kelpies, near Falkirk, has created the sculpture in tribute to Dunbar-born Muir, who went on to play a key role in the formation of the US national park system.The sculpture will be sited off the A, near to Dunbarrsquos McDonaldrsquos and Asda, and was selected by Hallhill Development Ltd.The developer has been involved in the construction of more than  houses in the south of the town and the statue has been created through the Percent for Art Scheme, which is a condition of planning consent.Ken Ross, from Hallhill Development Ltd, stressed there was not ldquoan exact date as yet but discussions were ongoing and the bear could be in place by April  ndash Muirrsquos birthday.

title: new-sculpture-could-be-created-at-dunbar-harbour
story: Dunbar Harbour Trust , which manages the harbour, is looking to create a timber-clad storage facility for harbour users at the western end of the harbour, near the castle.The plans, which have been submitted to East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department, also show a sculpture, although Steven Anderson, from DHT, was keen to stress that that aspect of the project was secondary to the storage building.A design statement included within the application said: ldquoWithin the application the main structure is a timber-clad storage facility for harbour activities, broken into six inidual units.ldquoThe other components are placement of sculpture and associated groundworks, access, seating, lighting and CCTV provision, the latter on approach to the storage area.Mr Anderson said improvements had been carried out at the Battery and the Propeller, with DHT now hoping to enhance this section of the harbour.He said: ldquoThe primary goal of the project is to create a new storage space and workshops for the harbour users and to improve the general environment.Photographs of the sculpture are included in the planning application, which Mr Anderson described as an ldquoindustrial piece. Funding for artwork would come from external organisations and DHT.

title: snp-announce-candidate-for-by-election
story: Lorraine Glass will be up against Neal Black , Stuart Crawfordand Craig Hoyat the by-election, which is due to take place on May .The by-election was triggered following the resignation of Conservative councillor Brian Small.Ms Glass was constituency support manager for George Kerevan MP and currently works for Joanna Cherry QC MP as her senior case worker.She said: ldquoI am delighted to be selected as the SNP candidate for the upcoming by-election.ldquoIf elected I will be part of a demanding opposition to the Labour administration, who with the support of the Tories are raising rents and council tax, closing our sports cregraveche and stopping our childrenrsquos music tuition.ldquoMy priority will always be to stand up for constituents.The mum of three daughters was born in Haddington and has lived most of her le in the town, having been educated at Knox Academy before going on to Napier University and gaining a degree in accounting and a post-graduate diploma in psychotherapy.She worked extensively with homeless people and people with mental health illness as a housing support manager.

title: lord-david-steel-pulls-out-of-fringe-by-the-sea-after-party-suspension
story: North Berwick festival Fringe by the Sea has said that Lord Steel has withdrawn from the programme after he was suspended from the Liberal Democrats.The former leader of the Lib Dems, Lord Steel was suspended after his dealings with the late Cyril Smith came to light.Cyril Smith MP was investigated by the police for child abuse offences in .Lord Steel stated that he had "assumed" that Cyril Smith had committed the offences after raising the question with him at the time, but didnrsquot pursue it, adding it ldquohad been properly a matter for the police and the council, and not for me as he was neither an MP nor even a member of the Liberal Party at the time. I was in no position to reopen the investigation.Cyril Smith was a Labour councillor in Rochdale in the s before becoming a Liberal. He then served the town as Liberal and then Liberal Democrat MP between  and .More allegations that he had been abusing young boys throughout his time in Rochdale emerged after his death in .A festival spokesperson said: ldquoThis morning, we received notication from David Steel that, upon legal advice, he is withdrawing from Fringe by the Sea events, as it is not known how long the party enquiry will take."We are securing an alternative host for the Lunchtime Conversations with Alexander McCall Smith and Val McDermid and will make a further announcement in due course."

title: speed-camera-van-to-be-deployed-on-a198-at-aberlady
story: The East Safety Camera Unit is set to start a "short-term deployment" from April  until June  on the A, west of Aberlady.The vehicle will be in place to help enforce the mph speed limiton the road andreduce speeds in an area where there have been four collisions, which resulted in one death.Andy Jones, East Safety Camera Unit manager, said: ldquoThe A is an extremely popular route, used by motorcyclists and cyclists."Due to the concerning number of collisions on this route, we will be enforcing in this area to encourage improved driver behaviour and compliance with the speed limit.Chief Inspector Stevie Duncan, outgoing East Lothian area commander, said: ldquoMotorists driving above the speed limit are more at risk of losing control of their vehicle and have less time to react to changing conditions. The consequences of this can be fatal."We are simply asking drivers to adhere to the speed limit on this route, for the safety of all road users.

title: astonishing-level-of-dog-dirt-on-sports-pitches-in-tranent
story: Sports clubs are working alongside East Lothian Council in a bid to reduce the number of people failing to clear up after their pets.Three blackspots in the area have been identied ndash Polson Park, Meadowmill and Ross High playing fields ndash and Councillor Colin McGinn described the amount of dog fouling as ldquoastonishing.He said: ldquoWhat is currently happening is the rugby club and Tranent Colts, who use Ross High playing fields, they have to send out a group of coaches or officials to walk the pitches and clear up the mess before they start playing. Runners at Meadowmill, or even the cricket club, are having to go out and make sure the training areas are clean before they start.ldquoFolk want to just turn up and get fit or improve their wellbeing without having to resort to clearing up dog mess before any activity.ldquoIt is irresponsible and pretty uncaring from people.Mr McGinn, who lives in Tranent, visited Meadowmill alongside representatives from ious East Lothian Council departments, including environmental health.The councillor described the situation as ldquoa disgrace, with a campaign to be launched in the coming weeks.Adam Hook, head coach at Ross High RFC, agreed it was a major problem.He said: ldquoIt is really frustrating. You can imagine we are trying to get warmed up and someone stops playing after spotting dog mess on the pitch. Someone then has got to take time out to clear it up and it impacts the warm up or during the game.Mr Hook was keen to see more regular patrols carried out by dog wardens in an attempt to catch irresponsible pet owners.He added: ldquoThey should hit them in the pocket and seethey do it again.ldquoIt is just total laziness. I know lots of people with dogs that would never dream of doing it.Phil Purves, chairman of Tranent Colts, agreed that it was a problem which was getting worse.He told the Courier: ldquoIt is very frustrating.ldquo[Clearing dog fouling] is something we have done pretty much all the time we have coached but it is out of control now.ldquoWe had a game two weeks ago and had to clean up  piles off one pitch.The club has recently bought a dog fouling bin to be put near the playing fields in a bid to encourage owners to clean up after their pets.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe council has noted an increase in complaints about dog fouling in recent weeks, particularly within grass sports areas and school grounds.ldquoOptions are currently being considered as to how best to tackle this situation and will be communicated in due course. In the meantime, all dog owners are reminded of their legal and moral responsibility to clean up after their dog and dispose of the waste properly.

title: jade-goody-saved-my-life
story: Sarah Thurston, ,had a radical hysterectomy in  after putting off smear tests for years until she heard about Goodyrsquos death.She said: ldquoJade Goody was my dental nurse at a practice in Covent Garden in London.ldquoI remember when she first got on to Big Brother, everybody in the dental practice was very excited for her.ldquoWhen she died in , I was living in Greece but was over in the UK for a few days. It really hit home to me and I thought lsquoBlimey, this is so sad.rsquoldquoWhen I had moved to Greece, I kept receiving the invites from my English GP to go for my smear test but I was never in the UK long enough to take them up.ldquoI didnrsquot get round to going in Greece because I didnrsquot know how to go about it.ldquoI thought lsquoNobody in my family has ever had cancer, sod it, it doesnrsquot matterrsquo.ldquoBut once Jade died, I thought I really must do something about it and so I eventually booked myself in for a smear test in Greece.Ms Thurston was diagnosed with an infection and given drugs to clear it up but then developed other symptoms, including bleeding after intercourse.In October , she was admitted to hospital as an emergency andwent on to have a radical hysterectomy,  cycles of radiotherapy and several cycles of chemotherapy.She has now been cancer-free for more than seven years.ldquoJade Goody saved my le, she said.ldquoHad I not been in England when the news of her death was everywhere, I would never have bothered getting a smear test and I would not have sought to follow up once I started bleeding.ldquoI was going through the menopause at that time and I would have put those symptoms down to the menopause.ldquoI would urge any woman to get their symptoms checked and to go for regular smear tests.

title: two-in-five-scots-feel-powerless-over-brexit-survey
story: And around one in five people said the situation surrounding Britainrsquos exit from the EU has caused them anxiety or high stress levels.The negative emotions were felt both by those who voted
